title: HLA-A★3101 and Carbamazepine-Induced Hypersensitivity Reactions in Europeans
summary: This study investigates the association between the HLA-A★3101 allele and hypersensitivity reactions induced by carbamazepine in individuals of European descent. It identifies HLA-A★3101 as a significant genetic risk factor for multiple forms of carbamazepine-induced hypersensitivity, including the hypersensitivity syndrome, maculopapular exanthema, and Stevens-Johnson syndrome/toxic epidermal necrolysis (SJS-TEN). The allele's presence was associated with increased risk, shifting the probability of hypersensitivity from approximately 5% to 26%. This finding highlights the importance of genetic testing for HLA-A★3101 in predicting carbamazepine hypersensitivity reactions among European populations.

study_parameters.Characteristics: SJS-TEN (Stevens-Johnson syndrome and toxic epidermal necrolysis)

var_drug_ann.Notes: Association confirmed with odds ratio of 12.41 for hypersensitivity syndrome.
var_drug_ann.Standardized Sentence: HLA-A★3101 is associated with increased hypersensitivity reactions carbamazepine in people of European descent.
Citations: The HLA-A★3101 allele, which has a prevalence of 2 to 5% in Northern European populations, was significantly associated with the hypersensitivity syndrome (P = 3.5x10−8).

Follow-up genotyping confirmed the variant as a risk factor for the hypersensitivity syndrome (odds ratio, 12.41; 95% confidence interval [CI], 1.27 to 121.03), maculopapular exanthema (odds ratio, 8.33; 95% CI, 3.59 to 19.36), and SJS-TEN (odds ratio, 25.93; 95% CI, 4.93 to 116.18).
The presence of the HLA-A★3101 allele increased the risk from 5.0% to 26.0%, whereas its absence reduced the risk from 5.0% to 3.8%.

var_pheno_ann.Notes: The HLA-A★3101 allele was significantly associated with carbamazepine-induced hypersensitivity reactions.
var_pheno_ann.Sentence: HLA-A★3101 is associated with increased likelihood of hypersensitivity syndrome when treated with carbamazepine in people of Northern European descent.
var_pheno_ann.Phenotype: hypersensitivity syndrome, maculopapular exanthema, Stevens-Johnson Syndrome
var_pheno_ann.Population types: in people of Northern European descent
Citations: The HLA-A★3101 allele, which has a prevalence of 2 to 5% in Northern European populations, was significantly associated with the hypersensitivity syndrome (P = 3.5x10−8).
The presence of the HLA-A★3101 allele was associated with carbamazepine-induced hypersensitivity reactions among subjects of Northern European ancestry.

This variant was seen in 40.0% of case subjects but in only 4.9% of control subjects. The top hit (rs1061235) had previously been shown to be a proxy for the HLA-A★3101 allele in persons of European descent.

var_fa_ann.Notes: The HLA-A*3101 allele is significantly associated with an increased risk of carbamazepine hypersensitivity reactions, with an odds ratio of 12.41 for hypersensitivity syndrome; confirmed by high-resolution sequence-based HLA typing.
var_fa_ann.Sentence: HLA-A*3101 is associated with increased risk of carbamazepine-induced hypersensitivity reactions as compared to non-carriers.
Citations: The HLA-A★3101 allele, which has a prevalence of 2 to 5% in Northern European populations, was significantly associated with the hypersensitivity syndrome (P = 3.5x10^−8^).

Follow-up genotyping confirmed the variant as a risk factor for the hypersensitivity syndrome (odds ratio, 12.41; 95% confidence interval [CI], 1.27 to 121.03), maculopapular exanthema (odds ratio, 8.33; 95% CI, 3.59 to 19.36), and SJS-TEN (odds ratio, 25.93; 95% CI, 4.93 to 116.18).

The presence of the HLA-A★3101 allele was associated with carbamazepine-induced hypersensitivity reactions among subjects of Northern European ancestry. The presence of the allele increased the risk from 5.0% to 26.0%, whereas its absence reduced the risk from 5.0% to 3.8%.
